coredata.dc:description: Composite polymer electrolytes (CPEs) are a promising alternative to flammable conventional liquid electrolytes for high-safety lithium-ion batteries. Establishing low-cost filler that enhances the amorphous nature of polymer in the CPEs and exhibits efficient Lewis acid-base interaction between fillers and anions of lithium salt, leading to improved dissociation of salts for enhanced conduction, is indispensable. In this work, for the first time, we construct a solid composite polymer electrolyte of poly(vinylidene fluoride hexafluoropropylene) embedded LaFeO3 (LFO) particles prepared by solution casting and electrospinning methods and study their performances. The 5 wt% LFO filler embedded CPE made by means of solution casting and electrospinning methods exhibited the highest ionic conductivity of 5.9 × 10-4 and 1.49 × 10-3 S cm−1 at room temperature and electrochemical stability window up to 4.6 and 4.45 V, respectively. Further, as-assembled solid-state lithium-ion batteries using electrospun CPE showed an initial discharge capacity of 166 mAh/g at 0.1C-rate and solution-casted CPE showed excellent cycling stability with 98.6 % capacity retention at 0.3C-rate even at 50th cycle. Such excellent performance originated from the introduction of the LFO particles as filler into the polymer matrix to enhance the ionic conductivity, mechanical strength and lithium metal compatibility of the resulting CPEs.

head.ce:title: Composite polymer electrolyte facilitated by enhanced amorphousity and Li+ conduction using LaFeO3-embedded PVDF-HFP for solid-state lithium metal battery

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Electrochemical Energy Storage Lab, Department of Green Energy Technology, Madanjeet School of Green Energy Technologies, Pondicherry University, Puducherry 605014, India

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Madanjeet School of Green Energy Technologies

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Electrochemical Energy Storage Lab, Department of Green Energy Technology, Madanjeet School of Green Energy Technologies, Pondicherry University, Puducherry 605014, India

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Composite polymer electrolytes (CPEs) are a promising alternative to flammable conventional liquid electrolytes for high-safety lithium-ion batteries. Establishing low-cost filler that enhances the amorphous nature of polymer in the CPEs and exhibits efficient Lewis acid-base interaction between fillers and anions of lithium salt, leading to improved dissociation of salts for enhanced conduction, is indispensable. In this work, for the first time, we construct a solid composite polymer electrolyte of poly(vinylidene fluoride hexafluoropropylene) embedded LaFeO3 (LFO) particles prepared by solution casting and electrospinning methods and study their performances. The 5 wt% LFO filler embedded CPE made by means of solution casting and electrospinning methods exhibited the highest ionic conductivity of 5.9 × 10-4 and 1.49 × 10-3 S cm−1 at room temperature and electrochemical stability window up to 4.6 and 4.45 V, respectively. Further, as-assembled solid-state lithium-ion batteries using electrospun CPE showed an initial discharge capacity of 166 mAh/g at 0.1C-rate and solution-casted CPE showed excellent cycling stability with 98.6 % capacity retention at 0.3C-rate even at 50th cycle. Such excellent performance originated from the introduction of the LFO particles as filler into the polymer matrix to enhance the ionic conductivity, mechanical strength and lithium metal compatibility of the resulting CPEs.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: It is widely known that the traditional lithium-ion batteries use liquid electrolytes that are inherently flammable in nature, though have advantages such as high ionic conductivity, low interfacial resistance, etc.[1,2] In recent years, there have been focuses on developing solid-state lithium-ion batteries to eliminate the usage of the liquid electrolytes to primarily address the safety concerns, thermal instability, and leakage.[3] Moving to solid electrolytes offer use of lithium metal as anode, lithium being lightweight, which has a high theoretical capacity of 3860 mA h g−1 and favorable low redox potential (−3.04 V versus the standard hydrogen electrode).[4] The solid-state electrolytes can be distinctly categorized into inorganic solid-state electrolytes (ISEs) and solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs). Unfortunately, both the categories suffer from major drawbacks such as grain boundary resistance at the interfaces by the ISEs, low mechanical strength and poor ionic conductivity by the SPEs.[5] These issues have given researchers an outlook towards developing a new category of the solid-state electrolytes, named composite polymer electrolytes (CPEs). A CPE generally comprises of a polymer matrix with lithium salts dispersed in it. The CPEs have good flexibility and low interfacial resistance due to the presence of polymer network. However, the CPEs still have issues of poor mechanical stability and limited conductivity. Thus, to increase the mechanical stability and improve the conductivity, different kinds of fillers are introduced into the polymer matrices.[6] The fillers embedded within the polymer matrix help reduce the crystallinity of the resulting CPE, which in turn improves the ionic conductivity.[7] The operative mechanism includes the strong interaction of the polymer matrix with the Lewis nature of the fillers which then weakens the interaction between the lithium salt and the polymer, making Li+ ions more labile, thereby amplifying the ionic conductivity.[8] Various polymers such as polyethylene oxide (PEO), poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP), polyacrylonitrile (PAN), poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA), etc. are explored as polymer host.[4] Among them, the PVDF-HFP is a popular host for the CPE due to the presence of functional groups with strong electron-withdrawing nature (−C-F) and high dielectric constant. Thus, the groups present in the PVDF-HFP matrix easily facilitate interaction with the anion part of the lithium salt, giving rise to more free charge carriers or labile Li+ ions to propagate.[9].

The search for the ideal filler for enhancing ionic conductivities in the polymer matrix to make it comparable to the liquid electrolytes, is still indispensable. The different classification of the fillers includes passive and active fillers. The passive fillers (e.g., ZrO2, Nb2O5, TiO2, CeO2, BaTiO3, Al2O3, ZSM-5 molecular sieve, g-C3N4) are generally insulating nature and they help in enhancing the amorphousity as well as the mechanical stability of the polymer matrix, whereas active fillers (e.g., Li0.3La0.557TiO3 (LLTO), Li10GeP2S12 (LGPS), Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO), Li1.3Al0.3Ti1.7(PO4)3 (LATP)) are inherent lithium-ion conductors at room temperature.[4] Inorganic fillers simultaneously function as a microstructural modifier to efficiently promote the densification of the polymer electrolytes, thereby improving its structural integrity enlarging the electrochemical window for compatibility with high-voltage cathodes for lithium-metal batteries.[10,11] Both categories of the fillers enhance the ionic conductivity by effective intermolecular interactions between the lithium salt, fillers and the polymer host. Incorporating lanthanum orthoferrite (LaFeO3) fillers into the PVDF-HFP is a reasonable choice to develop a new CPE as perovskite oxides (ABO3) are widely explored in various fields like catalysts, sensors, solid oxide fuel cells, solar cells, photocatalysis due to their enriched characteristics such as structural stability, variable oxidation states and abundant oxygen vacancies granting them considerable importance.[12] The LaFeO3 in particular has the ability to exhibit mixed conductivities i.e., ionic and electronic conductivities combined consequently improving its performance in various applications.[13] For example, Huang et al., synthesized hollow spherical LaFeO3 and employed it as an anode for lithium-ion battery that exhibited a discharge capacity of 981 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at current density of 500 mA g−1 implying that the spherical shape effectively shortened the Li+ transport distance.[14] Hu et al., effectively fabricated LaFeO3 and used it as supercapacitor electrode to achieve a specific capacitance of 183.6 F g−1 at current density of 1 A g−1.[15] Kuila et al., used LaMnO3 as a filler in the PEO-based CPE to enhance the ionic conductivity to a maximum of 2.60 × 10−4 S cm−1.[16] To the best of our knowledge, LaFeO3 has not been used as a filler in the PVDF-HFP polymer host to establish a new CPE for all solid-state lithium-ion batteries (ASSBs).

Thus, in this work, LaFeO3 nanoparticles were prepared through a facile hydrothermal method utilizing citric acid as the chelating agent to achieve size-controlled particles followed by calcination. The LaFeO3 particles were then embedded as inert filler in the PVDF-HFP matrix to form CPEs specifically by varying the filler concentration, two different routes, namely, solution casting and electrospinning were adapted in generating the CPEs. It turned out that tunable lithium-ion conductivity was established by varying the filler amount in the PVDF-HFP polymer matrix. Then, full cell solid-state lithium-ion batteries were assembled using lithium metal as anode and LiFePO4 (LFP) as cathode. Detailed analysis of ionic conductivity, transference number, electrochemical compatibility with lithium metal, charging-discharging cycle performances and coulombic efficiency were performed and reported here.

The LaFeO3 particles were prepared through a simple hydrothermal method followed by calcination. Each of lanthanum nitrate (5 mmol, Sigma Aldrich, 99 %) and ferric nitrate (5 mmol, Sigma Aldrich, 99 %) was dissolved in 60 ml of de-ionised water (DI) and stirred well to form a homogeneous solution. To this clear mixture, 20 mmol of citric acid (Sigma Aldrich, 99 %) was added to form a rusty-brown colour on continuous stirring for 30 min on a magnetic stirrer. The obtained content was transferred into a Teflon-lined 100 ml autoclave and subjected to hydrothermal treatment in a muffle furnace at 180 ˚C for 12 h. After hydrothermal treatment, the formed green precipitate was thoroughly washed with the DI and ethanol to get rid of the excess acid. The precipitate was then dried in a hot air oven overnight and further calcined at 800 ˚C for 2 h to get LaFeO3 perovskite. Hereafter, the prepared perovskite-type metal oxide, LaFeO3 is denoted as LFO.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of solution casted composite polymer electrolyte
ce:section.ce:para: At first, different weight percentages (0, 2.5, 5, 7.5 wt%) of the LFO were added in 10 ml of acetonitrile to form homogenous dispersion on continuous stirring for 2 h. Then, lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide, LiTFSI (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.95 %) and poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene) PVDF-HFP (Mw: 4,00,000, Sigma-Aldrich, 99.99 %), (1:2 in weight ratio) were added to the obtained dispersion and kept further stirring for 5 h at room temperature in an argon-filled glovebox (NICHWELL, α-1500u). The dispersion was then casted on a glass petri dish and the obtained CPE membrane was peeled off after drying. Hereafter, the solution casting prepared CPEs are denoted as SC-LFO 0, SC-LFO 2.5, SC-LFO 5 and SC-LFO 7.5 corresponding to the percentages of the LFO filler used 0, 2.5, 5 and 7.5 wt% in the PVDF-HFP polymer. Fig. 1 depicts the schematics of the steps involved in the preparation of the CPEs using the solution casting method.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of electrospun composite polymer electrolyte
ce:section.ce:para: The CPE membranes were also generated through electrospinning method. For this, different weight percentages (0, 2.5, 5, 7.5 wt%) of the LFO were added in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, Sigma Aldrich, 99.8 %) and acetone (7:3 v/v) to form homogenous dispersion on continuous stirring for 2 h. Then, 16 wt% of the PVDF-HFP was added and stirred until complete dissolution to form a viscous solution. The obtained solution was loaded in a 10 ml syringe and subjected to the syringe pump in the electrospinning machine (Royal enterprise, VPD30, India) to form the desired nanofiber membranes in the presence of a high voltage power supply. The parameters for the electrospinning process were maintained at 0.55 ml/hr flow-rate, 13 kV of voltage applied and a 15 cm distance between the needle tip and the collector plate. Thus, the free-standing membrane obtained was then transferred to an argon-filled glovebox. Hereafter, the prepared CPEs were denoted at ES-LFO 0, ES-LFO 2.5, ES-LFO 5 and ES-LFO 7.5 corresponding to the amount of the LFO filler used 0, 2.5, 5 and 7.5 wt% in the PVDF-HFP polymer. Fig. 1 also depicts the steps involved in the preparation of the CPEs using the electrospinning process.

The phase structure of the prepared LFO perovskite-type metal oxide and the CPEs were analyzed using powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Malvern Panalytical Aeries Research Edition 2D) with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5418 Å) operating in a 2θ range 5-80° at scan rate, 4°/min. Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR, Thermo Nicolet iS50, U.S.) was used to detect the functional groups present in the LFO and the CPEs, and Raman spectroscopy (Witec Confocal CRM200, Germany) was utilized to record the Raman profile of the LFO. The morphologies of the LFO and the CPEs were studied using a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Carl Zeiss SUPRA 55VP, Germany). For the LFO, high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM, JEOL JEM 2100 Plus, U.K.) along with energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDAX) was done for compositional studies. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC, TA Instruments SDT Q600, U.S.) were conducted to understand the melting transition for the CPEs in an ambient atmosphere in a temperature range of 0–250 ˚C at a heating rate of 5 ˚C min−1.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Coin-type cell fabrication and electrochemical measurements
ce:section.ce:para:
The ionic conductivity studies were performed by sandwiching the CPEs with stainless steel blocking electrodes (SS|CPE|SS) using an electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) (Admiral Squidstat 1387) at room temperature (RT, 25 ˚C) in the frequency range of 0.1 Hz − 1 MHz. The corresponding ionic conductivities were calculated using the following Eq. (1):

where, Δ V (=10 mV) is the applied polarization voltage (V), Io and Iss are the initial and steady-state currents (mA), Ro and Rss are the interfacial resistances at initial and steady-state (ohm) before and after polarization, respectively.[18] Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was performed on the (Li|CPE|SS) cell configuration across a voltage range of 3 – 5 V at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 to optimise the stable electrochemical voltage window. The stripping/plating behaviour was studied on the symmetric cells (Li|CPE|Li) at current densities in the range of 0.05 – 2 mA cm−2 and long-term cycling was performed at 0.05 mA cm−2 at 25 ˚C. Chronoamperometric analysis, LSV and stripping/plating cycling were conducted on the same electrochemical workstation (Biologics SP150). The performance of the all solid-state lithium-ion battery using the generated CPE was tested in a CR-2032 type coin cell. The cell (Li|CPE|LiFePO4) was assembled using a 14 mm Li disc as anode, a 14 mm LFP electrode as the cathode and the prepared CPEs punched into 19 mm disc as the electrolyte. For the LFP cathode preparation, a slurry was obtained after grinding LFP powder (Gelon LIB group), super P conductive carbon and PVDF binder thoroughly together in the wt.% ratio of 80:10:10 utilising N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) as the solvent. The obtained slurry was then coated on an aluminium (Al) foil (current collector) of 16 μm thickness using doctor-blade method and then kept for vacuum drying at 60 ˚C for 12 h. The coated Al-foil was then calendared before punching into 14 mm disc used as cathode. The LFP cathode had a mass loading of about 4.54 mg cm−2. The CR-2032 coin-type cell was assembled in a glovebox (Nichwell, α-1500u) filled with Argon gas having O2 and H2O concentration levels below 0.1 ppm. The full cell electrochemical performance was evaluated by means of galvanostatic charge–discharge studies at varying current rates (C-rates) in the voltage range of 2 – 4 V using a battery analyzer (Neware, C4008 − 5V50mA) at RT.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Crystal structure, morphology and thermal stability
ce:section.ce:para: The formation and its crystal structure of the hydrothermally-derived LFO were confirmed using the XRD pattern. The obtained XRD pattern is shown in Fig. 2 . The pattern exhibits clear high intense Bragg peaks that could be indexed to the orthorhombic LaFeO3 as per the standard JCPDS #37–1493 with lattice constants a = 5.565 Å, b = 7.838 Å, and c = 5.577 Å. The obtained sharp Bragg peaks suggest the high crystallinity and purity of the generated LFO.[13] Fig. 2 (a, b) also shows the XRD patterns of pristine PVDF-HFP along with the various composite polymer electrolytes prepared using the solution casting and the electrospinning methods. The pristine PVDF-HFP shows the characteristic Bragg peaks at 18 and 20˚ which correspond to the (020) and (110) planes of the VdF γ-phase (JCPDS #42–1649) comprising of the crystalline regions of PVDF-HFP and the peaks at 26 and 39˚ correspond to (021) and (131) planes of the VdF α-phase (JCPDS #42–1650) comprising of the amorphous regions.[19] It is noted that with the increase of the LFO filler content, the representative crystalline diffraction peaks at 18 and 20˚ of the PVDF-HFP are gradually suppressed with the emergence of the LFO filler peaks indicating the increase in amorphous nature of the polymer. This suggests the good interaction of the polymer with the filler, making the CPEs more amorphous in nature. The characteristic peaks of the salt (LiTFSI) were not observed in any of the CPEs generated indicating complete miscibility of the salt in the CPE. The XRD patterns vary significantly between the CPEs fabricated using the solution casting and the electrospinning methods due to differences in the molecular arrangement and structural characteristics occurring during the preparation of the CPEs. The XRD result of the LFO was substantiated using Raman and FT-IR data as discussed here. Fig. S1(a) depicts the Raman spectrum obtained for the LFO sample that has shifts at 268, 296, 413, 433 and 630 cm−1. The two shifts seen at 296 and 413 cm−1 are assigned to A1g mode and two other shifts at 268 and 433 cm−1 correspond to B3g mode. The peak at 630 cm−1 corresponds to two-photon scattering. The peak positions are in good agreement with the values previously reported for the LFO.[20,21] To identify the functional groups present in the LFO particles, the FT-IR spectrum was studied and shown in Fig. S1(b). The band observed at 3434 cm−1 is characteristic of the OH group. The presence of a peak at 2920 cm−1 corresponds to the adsorbed CO2 on the LFO surface. The presence of the carboxyl group is confirmed by the appearance of two bands at 2377 and 1630 cm−1. As the formation of the carbonate species on the surface of the perovskite-type oxides is known, thus the peaks at 1460 and 1030 cm−1 correspond to the principal vibration of CO3 2– group due to exposure to the ambient atmosphere. The strong peak at 555 cm−1 is attributed to the Fe-O stretching vibration which is a characteristic of the octahedral FeO6 groups present in the LFO.[22] The CPEs were further investigated using the FT-IR spectra as shown in Fig. 3 (a, b). The vibrational peaks observed at 1073, 1174, 1399 cm−1 are ascribed to bending vibration of C C, wagging vibration of CH2 and motion vibration of CF2 group in pristine PVDF-HFP, respectively. The vibrational frequencies observed at 602, 508 and 838 cm−1 are due to the crystalline α, β and γ-phases of the PVDF-HFP, respectively. The vibration due to the amorphous phase of the PVDF-HFP was observed at 877 cm−1.[23] The absence of the OH band at about 3500 cm−1 in the electrospun membrane as shown in Fig. S2 (a, b) confirms that they are hydrophobic in nature, whereas for the solution casting membranes, the OH band is clearly visible due to the presence of the LiTFSI which has moisture-absorbing nature when exposed to the moisture. In addition, the characteristic peak of the PVDF-HFP weakened and appeared as two peaks for the solution casting membranes indicating the interaction between the PVDF-HFP and the LiTFSI which stresses the polymer host and changes the crystalline phase formed, whereas there was no significant change in the PVDF-HFP peaks on addition of the fillers. The peak at 1634 cm−1 is ascribed to the complexation of the LiTFSI salt with the PVDF-HFP backbone.[24] Such homogeneous presence of the components in the CPEs is expected to result in better mechanical stability as well as ionic conductivity.

The morphological features and microstructures of the LFO sample were known using SEM and HR-TEM analyses. The SEM images shown in Fig. 4 (a, b) reveal the uniformly sized micro-spherical grains with a diameter of ∼ 5 µm. However, there seems slight rupture of some spheres with no significant agglomeration of the particles. Thus, the hydrothermal synthesis route with controlled temperature led

to the growth of the LFO microspheres. Further, SEM images were captured to characterize the morphology of the generated CPEs with and without filler as shown in Fig. 4 (c-f). For the solution casted membrane, the surface morphology has obvious variations after the addition of 5 wt% LFO particles into the PVDF-HFP matrix. The membrane without fillers shows microporous morphology with homogeneously dispersed Li-salt on the PVDF-HFP smooth polymer matrix. In contrast, a dense surface with irregularities are observed in the SC-LFO 5 membrane where the ∼ 5 µm LFO particles could be nicely wrapped by the polymer host, making it more amorphous thereby increasing its mechanical stability. The morphologies exhibited by the ES-LFO 0 and ES-LFO 5 membranes were fine regular fibers with even diameter without any midway rupture, forming a three-dimensional cross-linked structure with high porosity. Interestingly, there was no significant change in such fibrous morphology after the addition of the LFO particles which suggests that the LFO particles were well dispersed in the polymer matrix and caused no obstruction at the needle tip during the electrospinning process. To confirm the presence of the LFO filler particles in the membranes through SEM analysis, elemental mapping was performed as shown in Fig. 4 (g, h) for the SC-LFO 5 as well as ES-LFO 5. It is noted that La, Fe and O elements are homogeneously dispersed along with the polymer matrix in both. Thus, the XRD, FT-IR and SEM results confirm the incorporation of the LFO fillers into the PVDF-HFP matrix with enhanced amorphousity.

Additionally, HR-TEM analysis was done to gain further insights on the lattice fringes and the crystallinity of the LFO. Fig. 5 shows the HR-TEM images recorded. As is seen in Fig. 5(a), the average diameter of the LFO grains is about 300 nm. The observations reveal highly crystalline nature as clear lattice fringes are visible. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the space of crystal lattice fringes is 0.4 nm corresponding to the (101) plane of the orthorhombic perovskite structure. The appearance of the distinct rings with presence of bright spots in the SAED pattern shown in Fig. 5(c) also demonstrates crystalline structure. The diffraction rings are indexed to the (101), (121), (220), (202) and (240) planes of orthorhombic perovskite structure in accordance to the XRD pattern (JCPDS #37–1493).[25] In addition to the distinct rings, a few more bright spots suggests that the polycrystalline LFO material is made up of several crystalline grains orientated in different directions causing different sections of a crystal lattice reflect one another along an axis or plane. This can be substantiated with the absence of formation of secondary phases in the XRD pattern. Further, the elemental mappings and energy dispersive X-ray (EDAX) analysis of the LFO particles were recorded and shown in Fig. 5 (d, e) which confirmed the presence of La, Fe and O. From the peak intensity in EDAX profile, the obtained weight percentage of the elements are La (64.5 %), Fe (20.3 %) and O (15.2 %). To determine the thermal properties of the CPEs like glass transition temperature (Tg) and melting temperature (Tm), DSC study was conducted as shown in Fig. 6 (a, b). The glass transition temperatures of the ES-LFO 0, ES-LFO 2.5, ES-LFO 5 and ES-LFO 7.5 membranes are 34, 36, 33 and 36 ˚C, and for the SC-LFO 0, SC-LFO 2.5, SC-LFO 5 and SC-LFO 7.5 membranes are 51, 44, 43 and 63 ˚C, respectively. Thus, the addition of specific amount of the LFO filler acting as a solid plasticizer could drop the glass transition temperature significantly by reducing the crystalline regions of the PVDF-HFP, enhancing the segmental motion of the polymer chains that is expected to result in higher ionic conductivity. Notably, 5 wt% LFO addition was considered optimum for incorporation into the polymer matrix. Furthermore, melting endotherms were observed but the peaks were not sharply defined which could be due to the amorphous nature of the formed CPEs. The melting endothermic peaks at 163, 163, 163, and 162 °C are attributed to ES-LFO 0, ES-LFO 2.5, ES-LFO 5 and ES-LFO 7.5 membranes and the and the peaks at 140, 173, 187 and 141 ˚C correspond to the SC-LFO 0, SC- LFO 2.5, SC-LFO 5 and SC-LFO 7.5 membranes, respectively. These peaks can be ascribed to the confirmation of complete melting of the electrolytes.

The ionic conductivity of the generated CPEs was examined using impedance spectroscopy studies. The obtained Nyquist plots of the CPEs measured in the form of (SS|CPE|SS) are shown in Fig. 7 (a, b). It is noted that for all the CPEs, only spikes have been observed. This indicates good ionic conduction of the generated CPEs. From the impedance values, the estimated ionic conductivity of the CPEs using Eq. (1) is displayed in Table 1 . It is noticeable that the 5 wt% LFO containing CPEs made by the solution casting and the electrospinning methods exhibits the highest ionic conductivity of 0.59 × 10-3 (SC-LFO 5) and 1.49 × 10-3 S cm−1 (ES-LFO 5), respectively, due to segmental motion facilitated by low crystallinity and uniformity of the filler distribution on the polymer matrix. As the amorphous phase content dominates ion conduction in the polymer hosts, the 5 wt% LFO CPEs could improve ionic conductivity by causing long-range displacement of Li+ ions via segmental motion in the chains of the PVDF-HFP. As a result, it could slow down the rate of crystallization and retain the amorphous phase, leading to enhanced conductivity. With increase of the LFO filler content to 7 wt%, there seems agglomeration of the filler particles resulting in decrease of ionic conductivity. The higher ionic conductivity of the electrospun membrane suggests that the fibrous nature resulted in higher porosity with clear transport pathway thus improving Li+ ion conduction. The well-defined fibrous CPE could lead to easy Li+ mobility, resulting in high conduction. Thus, further studies were continued on the 5 wt% LFO added electrolytes (SC-LFO 5 and ES-LFO 5) as they showed highest ionic conductivity.

Electrochemical stability against lithium metal is a vital feature of the CPEs in applying to ASSBs. Hence, LSV studies were conducted for the cell (Li|CPE|SS) against high voltage and the stable voltage window at room temperature as shown in Fig. 7 (c, d). The electrochemical window of the 5 wt% LFO added CPE made from the solution casting (SC-LFO 5) and the electrospinning (ES-LFO 5) is as high as 4.6 and 4.45 V, respectively. The oxidation seems to occur at 4.25 and 4.4 V for the respective electrolytes without the filler. The addition of the LFO filler in the PVDF-HFP has resulted in notable stability even beyond 4.25 or 4.4 V. This demonstrates high electrochemical stability window of the SC-LFO 5 that has high oxidation potential and exceptional stability over cycling as compared to the ES-LFO 5. The lower electrochemical stability window observed for the ES-LFO 5 electrolyte is attributed to the differences in the mechanical and the interfacial stability due to varied molecular orientation and morphology. The chronoamperometry curves of the SC-LFO 5 and the ES-LFO 5 electrolytes in the form of the cell, (Li|CPE|Li) were adopted to investigate the lithium-ion transference number (tLi+) of the CPEs as shown in Fig. 8 (a, b). It was observed that with increase in time the initial current gradually decreases and attains a steady-state current. The Li-ion transference number is an essential parameter for assessing the electrolyte performance in terms of polarization and fast-charging capability. The Nyquist plots recorded for the symmetric cell (Li|CPE|Li) before and after polarisation are shown in Fig. 8 (c, d). This study was systematically carried out to estimate the change in the passivation layer resistance at the Li/CPE interface. The plots show convoluted semicircles, whose diameter is associated to the interface charge transfer resistance. The equivalent circuit depicted in the inset of Fig. 8 (c, d) was utilized to fit the Nyquist plots to determine the R0 and the Rss resistance values for calculation of the Li-ion transference number. The values of tLi+ for all the CPEs were calculated using Eq. (2) as stated above. The tLi+ for the SC-LFO 5 and the ES-LFO 5 are 0.78 and 0.45, respectively. Here, we observe a higher tLi+ for the SC-LFO 5 due to the presence of the LiTFSI in the solution casted CPE, contributing to the increased number of free Li+ ions, whereas highly ionisable salts cannot be used in electrospinning as the charged jet of solution is disrupted and leads to clogging at the needle tip thereby restricting the flow of the polymer solution to the collector plate. The LiTFSI in particular is also very moisture absorbing in nature which restricts its use in the PVDF-HFP dissolved in DMF in ambient atmosphere to avoid agglomeration. Thus, the tLi+ obtained for the SC-LFO 5 is higher compared to that of the ES-LFO 5. Such high tLi+ is expected to result in high rate capability (power density) which is one of the prime concerns in the ASSBs. Thus, the underlying mechanism for such a high transference number depends on the physical and chemical interactions between the bulk of the polymer and the LFO filler surface which involves the formation of Lewis acid-base interaction causing various ion-ion and ion–dipole interactions along with spontaneous polarization thus increasing the segmental motion of the Li+ ion in the PVDF-HFP matrix, leading to enhanced mobility, efficient ion transport and a higher Li+ transference number.

Further, to examine the stability of the CPE membranes against Li metal, lithium stripping/plating behaviour and cycling stability were performed using galvanostatic discharge–charge profiles in the symmetric (Li|CPE|Li) cells. The polarisation voltage profiles were recorded for both the SC-LFO 5 and the ES-LFO 5 electrolytes at a current density of 0.05 mA cm−2 for up to 300 h of cycling at 30 min charging and discharging time as shown in Fig. 9 (a). It is noted that the polarisation voltage for the SC- LFO 5 membrane was very low and showed an extremely flat and stable voltage plateau indicating immense cycling stability in contrast to the electrospun membrane, ES-LFO 5, which significantly has high polarisation voltage, causing it to short-circuit just after 200 h of cycling. This implies that the compatibility of the solution casted membrane (SC-LFO 5) with the lithium metal is better which could be due to more mechanically rigid nature as compared to the electrospun membrane (ES-LFO 5) which led to lithium dendrites piercing the membrane. For long cycling stability studies a particular current density of 0.05 mA cm−2 was chosen to show stable nature of plateau with minimum polarization due to uniform lithium deposition and stripping. On the cycled cell with the SC-LFO 5 membrane, further charging-discharging cycles were performed under various current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, 2 mA cm−2 at room temperature as shown in Fig. 9 (b). The polarization voltage thus increases eventually with higher current densities. At a current density of 2 mA cm−2, the polarization voltage exhibits obvious fluctuation, indicating interface instability between the CPE and the lithium metal. Thus, the electronic conductivity of LFO does not influence the overall galvanostatic long cycling charge–discharge studies as at room temperature it is an antiferromagnetic material, polarons that reside on neighboring Fe atoms have opposite spin directions. Hopping between these two sites requires flipping the spin direction of the polaron, which is unlikely to happen. Based on the aforementioned data, it seems that the addition of the LFO in to the PVDF-HFP matrix resulted in enhanced amorphousity, improved mechanical stability and ionic conductivity which are favourable for high electrochemical stability as well as cell capacity. The conduction mechanism operative in the generated CPEs is depicted in the schematic given in Fig. 10 . Here, the PVDF-HFP matrix and TFSI- anions function as Lewis base centers whereas, in the LFO, the Lewis acid centers (La, Fe) as well as Lewis base centers (O2–) co-exists. As the Li+ ions are recognized as a hard acid, several acid-base interactions such as ion-ion and ion–dipole interactions take place in these CPEs. Thus, the ionic conductivity results from the shift of the dynamic equilibrium towards more free ions which promotes the segmental motion of the Li+ ion in the PVDF-HFP matrix, leading to enhanced conductivity.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Performances of all Solid-State lithium-ion battery (Li|CPE|LFP)
ce:section.ce:para: To demonstrate the real-life application of the LFO incorporated in to the polymer electrolyte, solid-state lithium-ion full cells were assembled using the commercial LiFePO4 (LFP) as cathode, lithium metal as anode and each of the generated CPEs as solid-state electrolyte. The obtained representative three cycles galvanostatic charge–discharge profiles recorded at 0.1C-rate for the coin-type batteries having each of the SC-LFO 5 and the ES-LFO 5 solid-state electrolytes are shown in Fig. 11 (a, b). It is evident that the discharge profiles have clear plateaus at around 3.4 V, which is consistent with the typical redox behaviour of the LFP cathode vs Li.[26] During charging also, clear plateaus have been observed in both the CPEs. In Fig. 11 (c), it is noticeable that the ES-LFO 5 membrane shows excellent rate capability compared to the SC-LFO 5 and SC-LFO 0 CPE. Furthermore, the ES-LFO 5 exhibits high reversible capacities of 166, 158, 151, 141 and 110 mAh g−1 at current rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5 and 1C as compared to the SC-LFO 5 membrane showing capacities of 150, 147, 144, 131, 105 and 66 mAh g−1 at current rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, 1 and 2C, respectively. Interestingly, as high as 98 % of the theoretical capacity of the LFP (170 mAh g−1) at current rate of 0.1C observed for the ES-LFO 5 membrane, could be due to the low polarisation voltage of 0.12 V ascribing to the relatively low bulk resistance and the nanofibrous morphology which provided a stable framework and fast transport pathway for Li+ ions. It is also noted that both the SC-LFO 5 and the ES-LFO 5 membranes show almost similar discharge capacity to the initial capacity existed at 0.1C-rate even after subjecting the cell at different C-rates, implying high reversibility and rate capability. Unfortunately, the CPE made without the LFO filler exhibits poor discharge capacity as well as rate capability, as the CPE had limited mechanical stability as well as Li+ ion conduction. Notably, at a 1C-rate, the LFO-embedded CPE shows high discharge capacity, whereas the pristine CPE showed almost zero discharge capacity (Fig. 11 (c)). This demonstrates clear influence of the LFO filler embedded in the PVDF-HFP polymer matrix on the practical cell capacity. To examine the Li+ ion/electron diffusion kinetics in the CPEs impedance measurements were performed in the frequency range of 100 kHz–10 mHz using a CR-2032 coin cell. Fig. 12 (a) shows the Nyquist plots obtained for the full cells using the SC-LFO-5 and ES-LFO-5 CPEs. It is noted that the bulk resistance of the ES-LFO5 CPE is slightly more than SC-LFO5 which could be attributed to the better polymer and filler interaction in solution casted CPE as compared to the electrospun CPE having more densely packed aligned polymer fibers. Further, the long-term cycling performance of the SC-LFO 5 and the ES-LFO 5 was investigated at 0.3C-rate for 50 cycles, as shown in Fig. 13 (a, b). It is clearly visible that there is a significant declination in the capacity retention to 84.7 % at the 50th cycles for the ES- LFO 5 electrolyte, whereas the SC-LFO 5 electrolyte showed an excellent capacity retention as high as 98.6 % even at 50th cycle with high discharge capacity of 143 mAh g−1. The average stable coulombic efficiency of 97 % was observed. It is apparent that the cell (Li|ES-LFO5|LFP) with the ES-LFO 5 electrolyte shows better rate performance, whereas the cell (Li|SC-LFO5|LFP) with the SC-LFO 5 electrolyte shows prolonged stable cycle life performance. It seems that the solution casting method can bring about high cycling stability and the electrospinning method high capacity. The electrochemical performance of the CPEs in the present work is superior to that of majority of the reported metal oxide-based passive fillers as has been summarized in the Table 2 . The discharge capacity obtained in the present case is as high as 150 – 166 mAh g−1 at 0.1C-rate. Several of the literature reports are inferior to this performance. To assess the practicability of the electrolytes, two commercial light emitting diode (LED) bulb were successfully powered by the full cell solid-state lithium-ion battery and could continuously glow for more than 4 h on a single charge. This demonstrates the power delivery capability of the fabricated solid-state lithium-ion coin cell using the generated CPE. The inset in Fig. 13(a) shows the digital photograph of the LED bulbs being powered by the series connected coin cells (Li|SC-LFO5|LFP) and (Li|ES-LFO5|LFP).

To further study the compositional and structural integrity of the generated CPEs, the fabricated CR-2032 coin-type cell using the SC-LFO 5 and the ES-LFO 5 electrolytes were decrimped after galvanostatic charge–discharge long-term cycling studies. To gain insights, the CPEs were subjected to the XRD and the SEM analyses. Fig. 14 (a, b) shows the acquired XRD patterns of the SC-LFO 5 and the ES-LFO 5 electrolytes post cycling. It is noticeable that the LaFeO3 peaks are clearly visible even after long cycling, confirming the structural integrity of the LFO filler and there was no degradation. The sharp peak at diffraction angle 44.4˚ denotes the presence of LiF due to the solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer formed from the interface reaction between the lithium metal and the CPEs which dictates the kinetics of the lithium-ion transport by enhancing the interfacial contact, consequently, determining the cell performance.[35] The PVDF-HFP in both the SC-LFO 5 and the ES-LFO 5 electrolytes undergoes a dehydrofluorination reaction, which lead to the thick SEI layer with porous structure as substantiated by the SEM analyses as shown in Fig. 15 (a, b). The SC-LFO-5 electrolyte produced a more compact and uniform morphology which could improve the cycling stability of the cell during charging and discharging whereas the ES-LFO 5 electrolyte exhibited significantly larger voids between homogeneously wrinkled nanofibers which may be due to non-uniform Li deposition, thereby degrading cycling stability as compared to the SC-LFO 5.

In summary, micro-spherical LaFeO3 perovskite-type metal oxide as passive filler was prepared using hydrothermal method and incorporated in to the PVDF-HFP based polymer host and generated the solid-state electrolyte. The formation of the prepared LFO material was confirmed using XRD, Raman, FT-IR, SEM and HR-TEM. Further, the systematic characterisation of the CPEs done using XRD, FT-IR, DSC and SEM confirmed their structure, functional groups present, thermal stability and surface morphology. The strong Lewis acid-base interaction between the LFO particles with lithium salt and polymer backbone could enhance Li salt dissociation and reduce the crystallinity of the polymer along with improving its mechanical stability. The electrolytes, SC-LFO 5 and ES-LFO 5 exhibited high ionic conductivity of 5.9 × 10-4 and 1.49 × 10-3 S cm−1 and broad electrochemical stable voltage window of 4.6 and 4.45 V, respectively. Combined with the enhanced amorphousity and mechanical stability, facilitating segmental motion for the Li+ ion, and several interactions such as ion-ion, ion–dipole seemed responsible for the enhanced Li+ ion conduction. Owing to the excellent stability of the SC-LFO 5 CPE in comparison to the ES LFO 5 CPE against lithium metal up to 300 h of galvanostatic charge–discharge cycles, the solid-state lithium-ion full cell with the ES-LFO 5 solid-state electrolyte showed high initial discharge capacity of 166 mAh g−1 at 0.1C-rate, whereas the SC-LFO 5 CPE showed excellent cycling performances with high-capacity retention of 98.6 % with an average of 97 % coulombic efficiency at long 50 cycles. This study reveals that the solution casting method could be used to fabricate the CPE to get in high stability and the electrospinning method could be employed to fabricate the CPE to release high capacity of the ASSBs. Thus, this work is aimed towards establishing low-cost fillers with earth-abundant metals for developing all solid-state batteries with efficient cell performance for practical use.
